elements.content: Three new Mn­(II) coordination polymers (CPs) derived from the redox-active tetra­(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene ligand (TTF­(py)4), namely, {[MnCl2­(TTF­(py)4)]­·4CH2Cl2­·CH3OH} n (1), {[Mn­(N3)­(TTF­(py)4)]­·(ClO4)­·2CHCl3­·CH3OH)} n (2), and {[Mn­(dca)2­(TTF­(py)4)0.5]­·CH3OH} n (3) (dca = dicyanamide), were synthesized and characterized. Their topology and dimensionality are dependent on the counteranion used: Cl – forms a two-dimensional network, N3 – induces a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type three-dimensional (3D) framework, while dca results in a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type topological 3D framework. All compounds exhibit redox activity and display antiferromagnetic interactions. A single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation from 2 to 2′ induced by solvent exchange was observed and structurally characterized.
elements.clean_text: Three new Mn(II) coordination polymers (CPs) derived from the redox-active tetra(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene ligand (TTF(py)4), namely, {[MnCl2(TTF(py)4)]⋅4CH2Cl2⋅CH3OH} n  (1), {[Mn(N3)(TTF(py)4)]⋅(ClO4)⋅2CHCl3⋅CH3OH)} n  (2), and {[Mn(dca)2(TTF(py)4)0.5]⋅CH3OH} n  (3) (dca = dicyanamide), were synthesized and characterized. Their topology and dimensionality are dependent on the counteranion used: Cl -  forms a two-dimensional network, N3  -  induces a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type three-dimensional (3D) framework, while dca results in a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type topological 3D framework. All compounds exhibit redox activity and display antiferromagnetic interactions. A single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation from 2 to 2' induced by solvent exchange was observed and structurally characterized.

elements.content: Three coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetra­(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene ligand (TTF­(py)4) and different Mn­(II) precursors have been synthesized. They exhibit redox activity and antiferromagnetism. A crystal-to-crystal transformation induced by solvent exchange was studied. No significant intermolecular S···S and π···π interactions are observed in these complexes.
elements.clean_text: Three coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetra(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene ligand (TTF(py)4) and different Mn(II) precursors have been synthesized. They exhibit redox activity and antiferromagnetism. A crystal-to-crystal transformation induced by solvent exchange was studied. No significant intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions are observed in these complexes.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

The design and study of coordination polymers (CPs) are of significant interest due to the vast array of interesting structures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in catalysis, gas storage and separation, sensing, solar energy harvesting, and energy storage. The design of coordination compounds is influenced by several factors including, but not limited to, the coordination geometries of the metal ions, as well as the structures and functionalities of ligands, the solvent system, temperature, pH, and counterions.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

The design and study of coordination polymers (CPs) are of significant interest due to the vast array of interesting structures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in catalysis, gas storage and separation, sensing, solar energy harvesting, and energy storage. The design of coordination compounds is influenced by several factors including, but not limited to, the coordination geometries of the metal ions, as well as the structures and functionalities of ligands, the solvent system, temperature, pH, and counterions.

elements.content: The role of anions is very important in the synthesis of CPs due to their ability to influence coordination and hence self-assembly. Although efforts have been made to understand the effects of anion templating on the self-assembly process, the construction of different frameworks from the same ligand and metal remains a great challenge.
elements.clean_text: The role of anions is very important in the synthesis of CPs due to their ability to influence coordination and hence self-assembly. Although efforts have been made to understand the effects of anion templating on the self-assembly process, the construction of different frameworks from the same ligand and metal remains a great challenge.

elements.content: Designing ligands with specific structures and functions as “building blocks” is the key to constructing novel functional CPs. The redox noninnocent moiety tetrathiafulvalene (TTF, C6H4S4) and its derivatives have been used to synthesize multifunctional CPs with unprecedented diversity in their structure and physical properties–this may be attributed to the sulfur rich core and easily accessible oxidation states. Recently, our group reported several CPs built up from the redox-active tetra­(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene (TTF­(py)4, ) ligand. The relatively low oxidation potential of the TTF moiety has enabled the generation of its radical cation state by doping with iodine, which has been shown to tune the conductive, magnetic, and adsorptive properties.
elements.clean_text: Designing ligands with specific structures and functions as "building blocks" is the key to constructing novel functional CPs. The redox noninnocent moiety tetrathiafulvalene (TTF, C6H4S4) and its derivatives have been used to synthesize multifunctional CPs with unprecedented diversity in their structure and physical properties-this may be attributed to the sulfur rich core and easily accessible oxidation states. Recently, our group reported several CPs built up from the redox-active tetra(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene (TTF(py)4, ) ligand. The relatively low oxidation potential of the TTF moiety has enabled the generation of its radical cation state by doping with iodine, which has been shown to tune the conductive, magnetic, and adsorptive properties.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">

of TTF­(py)<sub>4</sub> Ligand</title>

elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular Structure of TTF(py)4 Ligand

elements.content: In order to investigate the influence of the counteranion on the architectures and properties of CPs, we explored the reactions of TTF­(py)4 with Mn­(II) salts comprising different anions, namely, Cl – , N3 – , and N­(CN) – . Here we report on three new Mn­(II)-based CPs, {[MnCl2­(TTF­(py)4)]­·4CH2Cl2­·CH3OH} n (1), {[Mn­(N3)­(TTF­(py)4)]­·(ClO4)­·2CHCl3­·CH3OH)} n (2), and {[Mn­(dca)2­(TTF­(py)4)0.5]­·CH3OH} n (3) (dca = dicyanamide), and probe their structures, magnetic properties, electrical conductivity, and electrochemical behavior. Solvent exchange of the frameworks leads to slight modulation of the conductive properties, demonstrating their potential as tunable components in molecular electronic devices.
elements.clean_text: In order to investigate the influence of the counteranion on the architectures and properties of CPs, we explored the reactions of TTF(py)4 with Mn(II) salts comprising different anions, namely, Cl - , N3  - , and N(CN) - . Here we report on three new Mn(II)-based CPs, {[MnCl2(TTF(py)4)]⋅4CH2Cl2⋅CH3OH} n  (1), {[Mn(N3)(TTF(py)4)]⋅(ClO4)⋅2CHCl3⋅CH3OH)} n  (2), and {[Mn(dca)2(TTF(py)4)0.5]⋅CH3OH} n  (3) (dca = dicyanamide), and probe their structures, magnetic properties, electrical conductivity, and electrochemical behavior. Solvent exchange of the frameworks leads to slight modulation of the conductive properties, demonstrating their potential as tunable components in molecular electronic devices.

elements.content: The self-assembly of different Mn­(II) salts with the TTF­(py)4 ligand was explored. Three crystalline CPs (1–3) were obtained via room temperature diffusion methods. In each system, the four pyridyl groups of TTF­(py)4 coordinate to Mn­(II) ions in the basal plane to form 4 × 4 layers with axial positions occupied by chloride ions to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets as in {[MnCl2­(TTF­(py)4)]­·4CH2Cl2­·CH3OH} n (1) or azide and dicyanamide ligands that bridge adjacent layers to give three-dimensional (3D) frameworks {[Mn­(N3)­(TTF­(py)4)]­·(ClO4)­·2CHCl3­·CH3OH)} n (2) and {[Mn­(dca)2­(TTF­(py)4)0.5]­·CH3OH} (3), respectively. Because of the different lengths, shapes, and directional bonding capabilities of the auxiliary ligand, the structure of 2 is non-interpenetrating, while that of 3 is interpenetrated. The characteristics and properties of the anions as well as the solvents used during crystallization resulted in distinct structures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Crystal Structures

The self-assembly of different Mn(II) salts with the TTF(py)4 ligand was explored. Three crystalline CPs (1-3) were obtained via room temperature diffusion methods. In each system, the four pyridyl groups of TTF(py)4 coordinate to Mn(II) ions in the basal plane to form 4 × 4 layers with axial positions occupied by chloride ions to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets as in {[MnCl2(TTF(py)4)]⋅4CH2Cl2⋅CH3OH} n  (1) or azide and dicyanamide ligands that bridge adjacent layers to give three-dimensional (3D) frameworks {[Mn(N3)(TTF(py)4)]⋅(ClO4)⋅2CHCl3⋅CH3OH)} n  (2) and {[Mn(dca)2(TTF(py)4)0.5]⋅CH3OH} (3), respectively. Because of the different lengths, shapes, and directional bonding capabilities of the auxiliary ligand, the structure of 2 is non-interpenetrating, while that of 3 is interpenetrated. The characteristics and properties of the anions as well as the solvents used during crystallization resulted in distinct structures.

wR 2 = [∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

The geometries related to the TTF­(py)4 ligand such as the 4-pyridyl derivatives and the dihedral angles between the four pyridyl groups and TTF core contribute to the formation of CPs in the coordination-driven self-assembly. Thus, its reaction with MnCl2 favors the (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network. Therefore, the Mn­(II) ions are six-coordinated with four equatorial N atoms (Mn–N = 2.297–2.344 Å) from four TTF­(py)4 ligands and two axial capping Cl – anions (Mn–Cl = 2.478–2.576 Å) (a). The TTF moieties are slightly curved giving dihedral angles of 11.63° at the S1–S2 fold, and 21.28° at the S3–S4 fold (Figure S1). Consequently, the [MnCl2TTF­(py)4] n layer is undulated (b), which results in two different voids marked as A (9.9 × 16.1 Å2) and B (9.9 × 10.1 Å2). These layers are stacked in an -ABAB- type along the crystallographic a-axis in a slipped stack fashion (c). No intermolecular S···S or π···π interactions were observed. The central CC bond length of the TTF is 1.335 Å. The bond lengths and angles of TTF­(py)4 are close to those reported for the neutral molecule, indicating that the TTF­(py)4 ligand is in its neutral state ().
elements.clean_text: The geometries related to the TTF(py)4 ligand such as the 4-pyridyl derivatives and the dihedral angles between the four pyridyl groups and TTF core contribute to the formation of CPs in the coordination-driven self-assembly. Thus, its reaction with MnCl2 favors the (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network. Therefore, the Mn(II) ions are six-coordinated with four equatorial N atoms (Mn-N = 2.297-2.344 Å) from four TTF(py)4 ligands and two axial capping Cl -  anions (Mn-Cl = 2.478-2.576 Å) (a). The TTF moieties are slightly curved giving dihedral angles of 11.63° at the S1-S2 fold, and 21.28° at the S3-S4 fold (Figure S1). Consequently, the [MnCl2TTF(py)4] n  layer is undulated (b), which results in two different voids marked as A (9.9 × 16.1 Å2) and B (9.9 × 10.1 Å2). These layers are stacked in an -ABAB- type along the crystallographic a-axis in a slipped stack fashion (c). No intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S or π⋅⋅⋅π interactions were observed. The central CC bond length of the TTF is 1.335 Å. The bond lengths and angles of TTF(py)4 are close to those reported for the neutral molecule, indicating that the TTF(py)4 ligand is in its neutral state ().

The reaction of TTF­(py)4 with Mn­(ClO4)2 in the presence of NaN3 resulted in the formation of the 3D framework 2, which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Its structure contains similar undulating layers {Mn­[TTF­(py)4]} n as in 1; however, in the case of 2, the azide ions bridge adjacent layers (Figure S2). The μ1,3-N3 coordination mode in the trans-positions results in a distorted [MnN6] octahedron, which contains four equatorial N atoms from four TTF­(py)4 ligands (a). The analysis of the topology reveals that the framework is a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type topological network (Table S2). The Mn–Nazide bond lengths (2.165–2.198 Å) are shorter than that of Mn–Npyridyl (2.250–2.286 Å)both sets of bond lengths are shorter than that of Mn–Npyridyl (2.297–2.344 Å) in 1. Similar to 1, the neutral TTF moiety is curved (Figure S1). The bond angles and lengths of the TTF­(py)4 are again close to those reported for neutral TTF (). The short azide linker appears to exert a pull on the layers, which results in intermolecular S···S and π···π interactions. The shortest C···C and S···S separations between the adjacent {Mn­[TTF­(py)4]} n layers are 3.41 and 3.70 Å, respectively (Figure S3). The presence of a single uncoordinated ClO4 – anion satisfies the charge requirement with Mn2+ and TTF0. To be noted are the zigzag chains of Mn-azide along the b-axis and the layers of {Mn­[TTF­(py)4]} n in the ac-plane, which undulates to accommodate the ClO4 – anion and the solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of TTF(py)4 with Mn(ClO4)2 in the presence of NaN3 resulted in the formation of the 3D framework 2, which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Its structure contains similar undulating layers {Mn[TTF(py)4]} n  as in 1; however, in the case of 2, the azide ions bridge adjacent layers (Figure S2). The μ1,3-N3 coordination mode in the trans-positions results in a distorted [MnN6] octahedron, which contains four equatorial N atoms from four TTF(py)4 ligands (a). The analysis of the topology reveals that the framework is a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type topological network (Table S2). The Mn-Nazide bond lengths (2.165-2.198 Å) are shorter than that of Mn-Npyridyl (2.250-2.286 Å)both sets of bond lengths are shorter than that of Mn-Npyridyl (2.297-2.344 Å) in 1. Similar to 1, the neutral TTF moiety is curved (Figure S1). The bond angles and lengths of the TTF(py)4 are again close to those reported for neutral TTF (). The short azide linker appears to exert a pull on the layers, which results in intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. The shortest C⋅⋅⋅C and S⋅⋅⋅S separations between the adjacent {Mn[TTF(py)4]} n  layers are 3.41 and 3.70 Å, respectively (Figure S3). The presence of a single uncoordinated ClO4  -  anion satisfies the charge requirement with Mn2+ and TTF0. To be noted are the zigzag chains of Mn-azide along the b-axis and the layers of {Mn[TTF(py)4]} n  in the ac-plane, which undulates to accommodate the ClO4  -  anion and the solvent molecules.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 2 showing (a) the coordination environment of Mn­(II) (30% probability displacement ellipsoids) and (b) the 3D network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: x + 1, y, z; B: x + 1, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; C: x, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; D: −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2).
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2 showing (a) the coordination environment of Mn(II) (30% probability displacement ellipsoids) and (b) the 3D network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: x + 1, y, z; B: x + 1, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; C: x, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; D: -x + 1, y + 1/2, -z + 1/2).

elements.content: The directional coordination ability of the dicyanamide ligand and its shape are responsible for major structural differences between compounds 3 and 2. In the former, there are two coordinating μ1,5-N­(CN)2 per formula unit, whereas in the latter there is only one μ1,3-N3. Consequently, compound 3 adopts a square grid of {Mn­(dca)2} n as found in many layered compounds containing this unit, while only chains of Mn–N3 are present in compound 2. This structural difference between compounds 2 and 3 means the coordination mode of Mn in compound 3 is now inverted, with four N from dca in the equatorial plane and two pyridines of TTF­(py)4 in the axial trans-positions. The increased distance between Mn atoms in the {Mn­(dca)2} n grid structure allows for the interpenetration of two framework nets. The 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework has a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type topology (Table S2, c, and Figure S4). In the absence of any counteranion, the TTF­(py)4 remains almost planar in 3. The planarity of the TTF and the interpenetration of the two frameworks leaves little space for solvent; thus, only one methanol molecule was found in the structure. The divergence of the pyridine on each side of the TTF is well-accommodated by the bend of the Mn-dca-Mn feature and thus minimizes the amount of strain in the framework. As distinct from compound 2, the neutral TTF moiety in compound 3 adopts a Z-like conformation. The central CC bond (1.337 Å) is slightly longer than that in compound 2 but is still consistent with a neutral TTF core.
elements.clean_text: The directional coordination ability of the dicyanamide ligand and its shape are responsible for major structural differences between compounds 3 and 2. In the former, there are two coordinating μ1,5-N(CN)2 per formula unit, whereas in the latter there is only one μ1,3-N3. Consequently, compound 3 adopts a square grid of {Mn(dca)2} n  as found in many layered compounds containing this unit, while only chains of Mn-N3 are present in compound 2. This structural difference between compounds 2 and 3 means the coordination mode of Mn in compound 3 is now inverted, with four N from dca in the equatorial plane and two pyridines of TTF(py)4 in the axial trans-positions. The increased distance between Mn atoms in the {Mn(dca)2} n  grid structure allows for the interpenetration of two framework nets. The 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework has a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type topology (Table S2, c, and Figure S4). In the absence of any counteranion, the TTF(py)4 remains almost planar in 3. The planarity of the TTF and the interpenetration of the two frameworks leaves little space for solvent; thus, only one methanol molecule was found in the structure. The divergence of the pyridine on each side of the TTF is well-accommodated by the bend of the Mn-dca-Mn feature and thus minimizes the amount of strain in the framework. As distinct from compound 2, the neutral TTF moiety in compound 3 adopts a Z-like conformation. The central CC bond (1.337 Å) is slightly longer than that in compound 2 but is still consistent with a neutral TTF core.

elements.content: Structure of 3 showing the (a) coordination environment for Mn­(II) (50% probability thermal ellipsoids), (b) 2D {Mn­(dca)2} n network, and (c) the 2-fold interpenetrated network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: −x + 2, −y + 1, −z + 1; B: −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; C: −x, y – 1/2, −z + 1/2; D: x, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2; E: x, −y + 1/2, z – 1/2).
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of 3 showing the (a) coordination environment for Mn(II) (50% probability thermal ellipsoids), (b) 2D {Mn(dca)2} n  network, and (c) the 2-fold interpenetrated network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: -x + 2, -y + 1, -z + 1; B: -x, y + 1/2, -z + 1/2; C: -x, y - 1/2, -z + 1/2; D: x, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; E: x, -y + 1/2, z - 1/2).

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of the compounds were measured on cooling in an applied field of 1 kOe (), and the isothermal magnetizations at 2 K were measured for the two 3D framework compounds (). Major differences were observed in the susceptibilities of the three compounds. 1 exhibits a Curie–Weiss behavior over the whole temperature region with a Weiss temperature of 0.35 K, suggesting that the exchange between neighboring manganese centers through the TTF­(py)4 ligand within the layer is relatively small. The lower susceptibilities for 2 and 3 at low temperatures are a clear indication of the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling. With the knowledge that the exchange within the layer is small, we modeled the temperature dependence of the susceptibility for 2 and 3 assuming magnetic interactions only through the bridging azide in 2 and dicyanamide in 3 (). As the chain is a regular one, we employed the one-dimensional formulation of Fisher for chains of classical spins. The Hamiltonian being H = − J ∑ S i S i + 1 and the susceptibility is given as χ = ( Ng 2 μ B 2 S ( S + 1 ) / 3 k T ) ( 1 + u ) / ( 1 − u ) where u is the Langevin function u = coth [ JS ( S + 1 ) / k T ] − [ k T / JS ( S + 1 ) ]
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of the compounds were measured on cooling in an applied field of 1 kOe (), and the isothermal magnetizations at 2 K were measured for the two 3D framework compounds (). Major differences were observed in the susceptibilities of the three compounds. 1 exhibits a Curie-Weiss behavior over the whole temperature region with a Weiss temperature of 0.35 K, suggesting that the exchange between neighboring manganese centers through the TTF(py)4 ligand within the layer is relatively small. The lower susceptibilities for 2 and 3 at low temperatures are a clear indication of the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling. With the knowledge that the exchange within the layer is small, we modeled the temperature dependence of the susceptibility for 2 and 3 assuming magnetic interactions only through the bridging azide in 2 and dicyanamide in 3 (). As the chain is a regular one, we employed the one-dimensional formulation of Fisher for chains of classical spins. The Hamiltonian being    H = - J ∑    S   i     S   i + 1      and the susceptibility is given as    χ =  (   Ng   2       μ   B     2   S  ( S + 1 )  / 3 k T )   ( 1 + u )  /  ( 1 - u )    where u is the Langevin function    u = coth  [ JS  ( S + 1 )  / k T ]  -  [ k T / JS  ( S + 1 )  ]

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the susceptibilities of the three compounds (symbols) and the fits to the data (lines). Data for 1 were fitted to the Curie–Weiss function and those for 2 and 3 to the one-dimensional Fisher model of classical spins.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the susceptibilities of the three compounds (symbols) and the fits to the data (lines). Data for 1 were fitted to the Curie-Weiss function and those for 2 and 3 to the one-dimensional Fisher model of classical spins.

elements.content: Isothermal magnetizations at 2 K for 2 and 3. Symbols represent the experimental data, and the lines are only to guide the eyes.
elements.clean_text: 5  Isothermal magnetizations at 2 K for 2 and 3. Symbols represent the experimental data, and the lines are only to guide the eyes.

elements.content: The data for 2 yielded an acceptable fit with a J value of −0.32 K, but for 3 an additional contribution accounting for a Curie tail at low temperatures was required and the refined J is −5.8 K. These values for J comply with the common trend that the short and high bonding multiplicity of azide results in strong exchange compared to a relatively low one for the long and low bonding multiplicity dicyanamide. The g-values of 2.05 in each case are experimentally acceptable for an isotropic divalent manganese ion (S = 5/2, L = 0, 6 A).
elements.clean_text: The data for 2 yielded an acceptable fit with a J value of -0.32 K, but for 3 an additional contribution accounting for a Curie tail at low temperatures was required and the refined J is -5.8 K. These values for J comply with the common trend that the short and high bonding multiplicity of azide results in strong exchange compared to a relatively low one for the long and low bonding multiplicity dicyanamide. The g-values of 2.05 in each case are experimentally acceptable for an isotropic divalent manganese ion (S = 5/2, L = 0, 6 A).

elements.content: The contrasting isothermal magnetizations at 2 K for 2 and 3 () reflect the different strengths of the exchange interaction between the two different chains as found in the susceptibility data. It is clear that the shorter azide bridge with a high bonding multiplicity results in a stronger exchange between manganese neighbors than the longer and relatively low bonding multiplicity dicyanamide.
elements.clean_text: The contrasting isothermal magnetizations at 2 K for 2 and 3 () reflect the different strengths of the exchange interaction between the two different chains as found in the susceptibility data. It is clear that the shorter azide bridge with a high bonding multiplicity results in a stronger exchange between manganese neighbors than the longer and relatively low bonding multiplicity dicyanamide.

elements.content: Solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) of compounds 1–3 were conducted to study their redox behaviors. The electrochemical parameters are given in . CV diagrams of compounds 1–3 show the expected TTF processes.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Electrochemistry

Solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) of compounds 1-3 were conducted to study their redox behaviors. The electrochemical parameters are given in . CV diagrams of compounds 1-3 show the expected TTF processes.

elements.content:
Redox Potentials of TTF­(py)<sub>4</sub> and Complexes <bold>1</bold>, <bold>2</bold>, and <bold>3</bold> redox potentials (V) vs Fc/Fc+ Redox Couple 1 2 3 TTF/TTF•+ 0.48 0.24 0.27 TTF•+/TTF2+ 0.90 0.62 0.60 Red1 –2.17 Mn2+/3+ 0.21, –0.36

Reported values are E onset potentials of irreversible processes.

The CV diagrams of the three compounds measured in the [(n-C4H9)4N]­PF6/CH3CN electrolyte exhibited two irreversible processes in the anodic region due to the TTF core ( and Figure S7). The first process (at 0.48 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 1, 0.24 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 2, and 0.27 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 3) was assigned to the TTF/TTF•+ redox couple, while the second quasi-reversible process (at 0.90 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 1, 0.62 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 2, and 0.60 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 3) was due to the TTF•+/TTF2+ redox couple. For 2, the broad reductive process at −2.17 V vs Fc/Fc+ can be attributed to a combination of reduction of the pyridyl rings within the ligand in addition to reduction of the azide present in the framework. The large anodic shift of the TTF oxidation processes when compared to the processes of the ligand in the solution state may be a consequence of the ligand coordination to the Mn center.
elements.clean_text: The CV diagrams of the three compounds measured in the [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN electrolyte exhibited two irreversible processes in the anodic region due to the TTF core ( and Figure S7). The first process (at 0.48 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 1, 0.24 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 2, and 0.27 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 3) was assigned to the TTF/TTF⋅+ redox couple, while the second quasi-reversible process (at 0.90 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 1, 0.62 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 2, and 0.60 V vs. Fc/Fc+ for 3) was due to the TTF⋅+/TTF2+ redox couple. For 2, the broad reductive process at -2.17 V vs Fc/Fc+ can be attributed to a combination of reduction of the pyridyl rings within the ligand in addition to reduction of the azide present in the framework. The large anodic shift of the TTF oxidation processes when compared to the processes of the ligand in the solution state may be a consequence of the ligand coordination to the Mn center.

elements.clean_text: 6  Solid-state cyclic voltammogram at scan rates of 100 and 1000 mV/s for 1. Measurements were performed in the [(n-C4H9)4N]PF6/CH3CN electrolyte. The arrow indicates the direction of the forward scan.

elements.content: CPs with high thermal and chemical stabilities can often retain their crystalline state through the process of gas adsorption, ion exchange, oxide-doping, temperature change, and so on. It is helpful to derive the structure–property relationship by resolving the crystal structures before and after the process. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) results suggest that the 3D frameworks of compounds 2 and 3 have good stability (Figure S5 and Figure S6). On this basis, the single crystal-to-single crystal transformation induced by solvent exchange was therefore conducted. The solvent-exchanged product compound 2′ was obtained by diffusing cyclohexane into dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) containing the crystals of 2 (which are insoluble in CH2Cl2). The crystal structure of 2 reveals an asymmetric unit containing one Mn, two dca, half a TTF­(py)4, one chloroform, and one methanol molecule. In contrast, the structure of 2′ possesses a similar 3D framework structure to 2, with the exception that the guest solvents CHCl3 and CH3OH were replaced by one CH2Cl2 and one cyclohexane (). The neutral TTF moiety also shows a slightly curved configuration (Figure S1). The central CC bond length of the TTF moiety is 1.333 Å, which is slightly longer than that in 2. Intermolecular S···S and π···π interactions were also observed, and the shortest separations of C···C and S···S between the adjacent {Mn­[TTF­(py)4]} n layers are 3.50 and 3.79 Å, respectively, which are slightly longer than those of 2 (Figure S2). For 3, solvent exchange was not observed due to the 2-fold interpenetration in the structure (Figure S5) where the narrow pore space is limited in accommodating the larger CH2Cl2 and cyclohexane molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent-Exchange

CPs with high thermal and chemical stabilities can often retain their crystalline state through the process of gas adsorption, ion exchange, oxide-doping, temperature change, and so on. It is helpful to derive the structure-property relationship by resolving the crystal structures before and after the process. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) results suggest that the 3D frameworks of compounds 2 and 3 have good stability (Figure S5 and Figure S6). On this basis, the single crystal-to-single crystal transformation induced by solvent exchange was therefore conducted. The solvent-exchanged product compound 2' was obtained by diffusing cyclohexane into dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) containing the crystals of 2 (which are insoluble in CH2Cl2). The crystal structure of 2 reveals an asymmetric unit containing one Mn, two dca, half a TTF(py)4, one chloroform, and one methanol molecule. In contrast, the structure of 2' possesses a similar 3D framework structure to 2, with the exception that the guest solvents CHCl3 and CH3OH were replaced by one CH2Cl2 and one cyclohexane (). The neutral TTF moiety also shows a slightly curved configuration (Figure S1). The central CC bond length of the TTF moiety is 1.333 Å, which is slightly longer than that in 2. Intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions were also observed, and the shortest separations of C⋅⋅⋅C and S⋅⋅⋅S between the adjacent {Mn[TTF(py)4]} n  layers are 3.50 and 3.79 Å, respectively, which are slightly longer than those of 2 (Figure S2). For 3, solvent exchange was not observed due to the 2-fold interpenetration in the structure (Figure S5) where the narrow pore space is limited in accommodating the larger CH2Cl2 and cyclohexane molecules.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 2′ showing the (a) coordination environment of Mn­(II) (30% probability displacement ellipsoids) and (b) the 3D network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: 2 – x, −y, 1 – z; B: 1 + x, +y, +z; C: +x, 3/2 – y, 1/2 + z; D: 1 + x, 3/2 – y, 1/2 + z; E: 2 – x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 – z).
elements.clean_text: 7  Crystal structure of 2' showing the (a) coordination environment of Mn(II) (30% probability displacement ellipsoids) and (b) the 3D network. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: 2 - x, -y, 1 - z; B: 1 + x, +y, +z; C: +x, 3/2 - y, 1/2 + z; D: 1 + x, 3/2 - y, 1/2 + z; E: 2 - x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 - z).

elements.content: The room temperature electrical conductivities measured by the two-probe method on the pelleted powder samples for 1, 2, 3, and 2′ are 2.0 × 10–10, 1.5 × 10–9, 4.2 × 10–9, and 6.3 × 10–9 S/cm, respectively (Figure S8). The conductivity increase of 1 order of magnitude for compounds 2 and 3 (compared to 1) may result from the shorter intermolecular π···π and S···S interactions. The relatively low conductivities may be considered a consequence of the absence of continuous and significant intermolecular S···S and π···π interactions, which can act as conductive pathways.
elements.clean_text:
Conducting Properties

The room temperature electrical conductivities measured by the two-probe method on the pelleted powder samples for 1, 2, 3, and 2' are 2.0 × 10-10, 1.5 × 10-9, 4.2 × 10-9, and 6.3 × 10-9 S/cm, respectively (Figure S8). The conductivity increase of 1 order of magnitude for compounds 2 and 3 (compared to 1) may result from the shorter intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π and S⋅⋅⋅S interactions. The relatively low conductivities may be considered a consequence of the absence of continuous and significant intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, which can act as conductive pathways.

elements.content: Three manganese CPs built up from the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrapyridyl ligand were prepared and structurally characterized. Structural analysis shows that the anions play an important role in governing the structures of the CPs. Compound 1 exhibited a (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network which stacks in an -ABAB- stacking type. Compound 2 showed a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type topological network, while compound 3 presented a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type 3D framework. The magnetic measurement shows that the three compounds are antiferromagnetic. In addition, the solid-state electrochemical studies on the three compounds revealed that the CPs retained the redox activity of the TTF moiety. The results showed that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into CPs may be an effective way for synthesizing functional redox-active materials. Owing to their potential for constructing multifunctional materials, we will try to obtain more TTF­(py)4-based CPs with novel structures and interesting chemical and physical properties in our further work.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three manganese CPs built up from the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrapyridyl ligand were prepared and structurally characterized. Structural analysis shows that the anions play an important role in governing the structures of the CPs. Compound 1 exhibited a (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network which stacks in an -ABAB- stacking type. Compound 2 showed a (4,6)-connected binodal sqc11-type topological network, while compound 3 presented a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,6)-connected binodal sqc173-type 3D framework. The magnetic measurement shows that the three compounds are antiferromagnetic. In addition, the solid-state electrochemical studies on the three compounds revealed that the CPs retained the redox activity of the TTF moiety. The results showed that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into CPs may be an effective way for synthesizing functional redox-active materials. Owing to their potential for constructing multifunctional materials, we will try to obtain more TTF(py)4-based CPs with novel structures and interesting chemical and physical properties in our further work.

Conducting Properties

The room temperature electrical conductivities measured by the two-probe method on the pelleted powder samples for 1, 2, 3, and 2' are 2.0 × 10-10, 1.5 × 10-9, 4.2 × 10-9, and 6.3 × 10-9 S/cm, respectively (Figure S8). The conductivity increase of 1 order of magnitude for compounds 2 and 3 (compared to 1) may result from the shorter intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π and S⋅⋅⋅S interactions. The relatively low conductivities may be considered a consequence of the absence of continuous and significant intermolecular S⋅⋅⋅S and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, which can act as conductive pathways.

Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: A: -x + 2, -y + 1, -z + 1; B: -x, y + 1/2, -z + 1/2; C: -x, y - 1/2, -z + 1/2; D: x, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2; E: x, -y + 1/2, z - 1/2).

cln_elements.content: Temperature dependence of the susceptibilities of the three compounds (symbols) and the fits to the data (lines). Data for 1 were fitted to the Curie–Weiss function and those for 2 and 3 to the one-dimensional Fisher model of classical spins.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the susceptibilities of the three compounds (symbols) and the fits to the data (lines). Data for 1 were fitted to the Curie-Weiss function and those for 2 and 3 to the one-dimensional Fisher model of classical spins.

cln_elements.content: Isothermal magnetizations at 2 K for 2 and 3. Symbols represent the experimental data, and the lines are only to guide the eyes.

metadata.title:
Progressive Structure Designing and Property Tuning
of Manganese(II) Coordination Polymers with the Tetra(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene
Ligand
